final_answer.precision_note: 4 s.f. from 0.150 M NaOH and 23.40 cm3 / 25.00 cm3 volume data.

method: Use n = cV for NaOH: n(NaOH) = 0.150 × 0.02340 = 3.51×10^-3 mol. From H2SO4 + 2NaOH, one H2SO4 consumes 2 moles NaOH, so n(H2SO4) = 3.51×10^-3 / 2 = 1.755×10^-3 mol. Divide by acid volume 25.00 cm3 (0.02500 dm3): c(H2SO4) = 1.755×10^-3 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: H2SO4 moles are half the NaOH moles due to 1:2 stoichiometry.
Concentration is much smaller than NaOH concentration, as expected after dilution in 25.00 cm3 sample.
